instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.D6905: What is D6905? Diode sitting between PPBUS_G3H/PP18V5 charger voltage and PP3V42_G3H power supply input on very old Macbooks(before 2011), can die and cause PP3V42_G3H to be missing and have no input voltage. .
definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR: What is PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR? This is the input that comes from the charger..
definitions.PP1V2_S3: What is PP1V2_S3? PP1V2_S3 is a 1.2v power rail present when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state.
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..
definitions.PM_EN_P3V3_G3H: What is PM_EN_P3V3_G3H? PM_EN_P3V3_G3H is a signal that enables the PP3V3_G3H rail to turn on. This comes out of ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip; when missing, often is missing because of a bad ISL9239 or ISL9240 chip. .
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA: What is PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA? PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state that powers the SMC that comes from PP3V3_S5. A blown or corroded L4901 inductor behind it can kepe it from working, inductor number will differ depending on your board. .

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
Hello, first time poster here - not a repair shop owner - just decided to try and fix a macbook I acquired recently.

Unfortunately, I don't know the MacBooks history - just purchased it as defective for cheap with the only info given "It suddenly didn't turn on anymore".

The case seems eerily similar to [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-s5-rails-not-steady.50493/[/URL] but the thread seems to have died without reaching a conclusion

Here are some not-quite-highres pictures of the board: [IMG]https://linedot.org/images/Backcombined.jpg[/IMG]
[IMG]https://linedot.org/images/Frontcombined.jpg[/IMG]
SMC bypass did not work. Here are some measurements I performed so far:

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR</SIGNAL> = 20V
<SIGNAL>TBA_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> = 4.97V
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDA</SIGNAL> = 5.20V
<SIGNAL>TBA_VDDP</SIGNAL> = 5.20V
<SIGNAL>PM_EN_P3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 5.20V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.41V
<SIGNAL>SMC_AUX_OK</SIGNAL> = 3.41V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST</SIGNAL>* = 3.41V

<DIODE>D6905</DIODE>: 
  Pin 1: 13.04V
  Pin 2: 19.92V
  Pin 3: 19.66V

F7000: 13V both

<SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> = jumps between 0V and 3V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = jumps between 3V and 5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = jumps between 0V and 3V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_S0R</SIGNAL> = jumps between 0V and 3V
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> = jumps between 0mV and 23mV
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> = jumps between 0mV and 10mV

<SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> = 3.40 V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5_SMC_VDDC</SIGNAL> = 1.22 V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PP1V_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S0G</SIGNAL> = 0V

<SIGNAL>P5VS4_EN</SIGNAL> = 0V 


<CHIP>U7890</CHIP>:

1 (<SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_REQ</SIGNAL>): 1.51V
2 (<SIGNAL>PMIC_EN_P3V3S5</SIGNAL>): jumps between 0V and 3V
3 (GND)
4 (<SIGNAL>PM_EN_PVXS5</SIGNAL>): jumps between 0V and 3V
5 (NC)
6 (<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL>): 3.41V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> = no short

<SIGNAL>PP1V_S3</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_S3</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S3</SIGNAL> = no short

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4_WLS</SIGNAL> = no short

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = no short
<SIGNAL>PPVCCPCH_S5G</SIGNAL> = no short

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5G</SIGNAL> = no short

<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> = short (Or just inductor (L8060,L1250,L1252,L1253,L1254) ?)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> = short (Or just inductor (L7930) ?)

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_SMC_VDDA</SIGNAL> = no short

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> = 0V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> = 0V

Considering I am seeing a small voltage on <SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> with the charger connected, I assume that those aren't shorted? Otherwise I would proceed by lifting the inductors and checking if the short remains. Can you help me with how I should proceed?

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

"<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> = short (Or just inductor (L8060,L1250,L1252,L1253,L1254) ?)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> = short (Or just inductor (L7930) ?)"
Post exact ohm value (NOT diode) to ground; measure 10-15s after power is removed.

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
Thanks for the welcome!

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL> ~ 0.2 Ohm (1.2-1.3 measured, 1.0-1.1 Ohm with just the probes (is my multimeter trash?))
<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> ~ 0.4 Ohm

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
Almost pure short, not good.
Lift L7930 and L8060; check where the short remain.

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
L7930 and L8060 lifted.
[IMG]https://linedot.org/images/L7930lifted.jpg[/IMG]

[IMG]https://linedot.org/images/L8060lifted.jpg[/IMG]


Both shorts still there. Same measurements.

Anything to try before injecting voltage into the rail?

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message: Which side of coils remain these shorts???

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
L8060:
Pin 1 (<SIGNAL>BANJO_SWVR1</SIGNAL>): no short, diode mode: out of range, resistance: OOR (>20MΩ)
Pin 2 (<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G_REG</SIGNAL>): short, diode mode: 0.004, resistance: 0.4 Ω

L7930:
Pin 1 (<SIGNAL>BANJO_SWVR2</SIGNAL>): no short, diode mode: 1.930, resistance: 890kΩ
Pin 2 (<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S5G</SIGNAL>): short, diode mode: 0.003, resistance: 0.2Ω

<SIGNAL>PP1V_S5G</SIGNAL> measured from pin 1 of <CAPACITOR>C8071</CAPACITOR>: short, diode mode: 0.004, resistance: 0.4Ω

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
CPU is the common point for both power supplies.
99% dead CPU...

threads.title: 840-00840-A 20V 0.01A S5 rails jumping
threads.message:
Well... French University of Christian Kings...

Thank you for the help!

Maybe I can find a repairable board for cheap somewhere
